Includes diplomatic relations (including the attempted kidnapping of US ambassador Brunson McKinley), elections and democratization, immigration policy, Elliott Abrams, William Fauntroy, commemorations of 1915-1934 US marine occupation of Haiti, among other subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about Haiti-US relations, including US ambassador Alvin Adams ("Bourik Chaje") and Vice-President Dan Quayle's visit to Haiti.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to Haiti-US relations and bilateral cooperation. Includes economic and development aid (USAID), multinational forces, Operation Uphold Democracy, diplomatic relations, immigration policy, PL-480, , visits of Hillary Clinton and Madeleine Albright in Haiti, the Abner Louima police brutality case, among other subjects. (Folders organized by year.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to Haiti-US relations and bilateral cooperation. Includes economic and development aid (USAID), multinational forces, Operation Uphold Democracy, diplomatic relations, immigration policy, PL-480, , visits of Hillary Clinton and Madeleine Albright in Haiti, the Abner Louima police brutality case, among other subjects. (Folders organized by year.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Jean Rabel massacre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the International Republican Institute (IRI), a supposedly nonpartisan US nonprofit democratization organization that many critics believed to be furthering the agenda and interests of the Republican party. In Haiti in particular, the IRI was involved in anti-Aristide activities. External materials include IRI promotional materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials (1998) and photocopy of essay "La question de la Navase" in Optique journal (1956) concerning the dispute between Haiti and the United States over Navassa Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about Patrick Elie's imprisonment in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the Rice Corporation affair, in which US senator Jesse Helms threatens the suspension of aid to Haiti after the Haitian government confiscated the largely US-owned Rice Corporation of Haiti. The Haitian authorities claimed that the Rice Corporation had committed customs fraud.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published texts by Jean Dominique. Includes "Louvri je pou kole zepòl" in Sèl magazine (July 1983), "Le fin du marronage : éléments pour une étude des mouvements de contestation populaire en Haïti" in Collectif Paroles magazine (May-December 1985).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Partial drafts (typewritten) of Jean Dominique's 1973 text on the Saut d'Eau pilgrimage (Ville Bonheur, ville mystère, ville misère) and 1974 editorial "Urbanisme ou utopie?"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Editorials by Jean Dominique. Subjects include the reopening of Radio Haiti, the sugar industry and the closing of the HASCO factory, the events of 28 November 1980, the 29 March 1987 constitutional referendum, democratization, the Conseil National de Gouvernement, strikes and demonstrations, labor unions, the life and death of Richard Brisson, the continuing threat posed by Macoutism and Duvalierism, the legacy of the Caco rebellion and the US occupation, the disappearance of Charlot Jacquelin, popular resistance and peasant movements, divisions within the Haitian left, the expulsion of Father Jean-Bertrand Aristide from the Salesian order, among other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Editorials by Jean Dominique. Includes "Privilège de l'executif ou Remacoutisation," "Privilège de l'executif ou Partage de pouvoir," "L'essentiel, sous les faux semblants," "L'enjeu de la Crise," and notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten notes by Jean Dominique about the St. Jean Bosco massacre, journalism during the years of the Duvalier regime, CIA involvement with Guatemala military, various topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Quelques réflexions sur un deuxième acte" responding to the Brandt-Stecher affair and Constantin Mayard-Paul (July 1976); another text on justice and the law.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: After Jean Dominique's assassination, Radio Haiti's staff returned to their archive to present some of his most important interviews, debates, editorials, and reporting from 1970 through 2000, including broadcasts on culture, politics, and the peasantry. Includes Radio Haiti's notes and introductions to these historical recordings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about national censuses.

did.unittitle: IHSI (Institut Haïtien de Statistiques et d'Informatique)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about the Institut Haïtien de Statistiques et d'Informatique (IHSI) and reports and publications by IHSI. Includes demographic studies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Labor unions and rights

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about the Ministère des Affaires Sociales. Includes the Code du Travail, policy and projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Obituaries (both by Radio Haiti and external sources) of political and cultural figures. Includes Jacques Large, Emmanuel Ambroise, Théodore Beaubrun (Languichatte), Max Chancy, Renaud Bernadin, Emile Ollivier, Roger Gaillard, Lobo Dyabavadra (Karl Marcel Casséus), Ansy Derose, Jean Desquiron, Coupé Cloué, Pradel Pompilus, Marie Antoine André, Jean-Robert Sabalat, Ernst Verdieu, Lydia Jeanty, Azor, Leslie Delatour, Paul Eugène Magloire, Marcel Gilbert, Martha Jean-Claude, Albert Mangonès, and Hervé Denis, among others. Also includes the suicide note of Claude René.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about population policy, the Secrétaire d'État à la Population, human development, overpopulation, statistics (poverty, AIDS, illiteracy, and others).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: SEJSSC

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about young people, grassroots youth movements, programs, activities and policies for young people.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about awards and prizes received by Radio Haiti and its journalists. Includes Jean Dominique's posthumous Michael S. Hooper Human Rights Award (2000) and Michèle Montas's Maria Moors Cabot Prize (2002).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: External press about Radio Haiti and/or Jean Dominique. Includes 1975 Le Nouvelliste article by Michèle Montas entitled "Trois Hommes parlent des Femmes" about a debate about Haitian women between Jean Dominique, Carlo Désinor, and Legrand Bijou; commentary on Dominique's reaction to the attack on Luc Nérée from Haïti Presse; Colonel Jean Valmé's denial of Radio Haiti's claims regarding a police raid on 2ème Avenue de Bolosse in September 1978; various round tables; Jean-Claude Duvalier's meetings with the press.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: External press about Radio Haiti and/or Jean Dominique. Includes remembrances of 28 November 1980, interview with Jean Dominique in Tap-Tap magazine, Washington Post on Radio Haiti's resistance in 1987 and repression after the 1991 coup d'état, articles in L'Union, Le Nouvelliste, and Le Monde. Also contains news on the 1995 destruction of Radio Haiti's AM transmitter in Drouillard. Article "Jean Dominique/Serge Beaulieu, '2 cabris de Thomazeau'" (faded fax, date unclear).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interview of Jean Dominique by Michèle Montas, published in Le Nouvelliste on 22 November 1972.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Complete and partial issues of Le Petit Samedi Soir about Radio Haiti and Jean Dominique, including the October 1980 arrest of Konpè Filo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Text of Michèle Montas's final editorial, announcing the closure of Radio Haiti.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Introductions to and notes on Jean Dominique's daily Face à l'Opinion interviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten schedules and detailed descriptions of Radio Haiti's daily programming. Folders arranged by year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten schedules and detailed descriptions of Radio Haiti's daily programming. Folders arranged by year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten schedules and detailed descriptions of Radio Haiti's daily programming. Folders arranged by year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Handwritten schedules and detailed descriptions of Radio Haiti's daily programming. Folders arranged by year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Schedules of Radio Haiti programming, notes on pogramming, internal memos to the newsroom, information regarding fees for sponsors and advertisers, correpondence. Also includes the birth certificate (1955) of one Dieu-Puissant Charles -- ordinary people would often come to Radio Haiti as a sort of communal "lost and found."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from attorney Osner Fevry to Jean Dominique from January 1980, apologizing for having wrongly claimed that Dominique was present at an event on 27 December 1979; undated Christmas card (perhaps 1989). 1987 letter to the direction of Radio Haiti about an abandoned child; communication from ZANTRAY; Uruguayan journalist Sergio Lago; letter from Ozzie Leonard of WNYE; and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Scripts for Radio Haiti's spots and jingles. Includes drafts of "On a tout essayé," the Entre Nous intro, "Kinan'm," jazz program intro ("Des rivages de Gorée..."), "Soti Coq Chante rive Rossignol...", Justice for Jean Dominiquespots ("Lò yo sasinen Dr Ary Bordes"), and others.

did.unittitle: Banner: Radio Haïti, 1330 am, L'écoute intelligente

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One red-and-blue banner of Mylar-type material measuring 87 x 29 inches: "Radio Haïti, 1330 am, l'écoute intelligente." Undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two rubber stamps, both undated. One says "Radio Haïti-Inter" and features the station's trademark vèvè symbol, as designed by Rose-Marie Desruisseau. The other says "Radio Haiti" in art deco font and has the call signs 4vw, 4vhw, and 4vrw.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reactions and contestations after Radio Haiti's reporting on the May 1978 elections in the Dominican Republic, and the Agence France Presse's dispatch based on Radio Haiti's reporting. Radio Haiti reported rumors that there had been a coup d'état, but did not report that there was in fact a coup d'état; AFP reported that there had been a coup d'état. Radio Haiti responds to the allegations.

did.unittitle: Tribute to Radio Haiti, planters in Léogâne

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti report on a tribute to the station by sugar planters in Léogâne, who honored Radio Haiti for their support in the struggle against counterfeit clairin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Press about and support for Radio Haiti following the military's 6 April 1989 attack on Radio Haiti. Includes an inventory of the damage, Jean Dominique's correspondence with Alfred Mentor (Director General of the Ministry of Information), statements of solidarity from Tèt Kole Ti Peyizan Ayisyen, the Soeurs de Sainte Anne, the Committee to Protect Journalists, Jeunesse Ouvrière Chrétienne, Léon Manus, TKL Saint Joseph, Mouvman Peyizan Papay, CATH labor union, LAPPH, Fritz Lebon, and others. Also includes Jean Dominique's statement of thanks for those who expressed solidarity, and two issues of Balance magazine from March 1989, on the repression leading up to the attack.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: November 28, 1980 crackdown; Repression of independent media;

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials related to the 1980 exile of Radio Haiti journalists, their return in 1986, and the solidarity campaign to relaunch Radio Haiti in 1986. Includes reporting on the return of Jean Dominique and Michèle Montas, Liliane Pierre-Paul, Konpè Filo, as well as non-Radio Haiti journalists such as Pierre Clitandre and Jean-Robert Hérard. Also includes several issues of Le Petit Samedi Soir about the "November 28 exiles." Also contains Jean Dominique's 1981 letter to Luis Teofilo Nuñez Arismendi of the Inter-American Press Association (SIP), thanking him and Venezuela for their support.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Violence against journalists

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials related to the 2001 attack on Radio Haiti journalist Jean-Robert Delciné by police in Cité Soleil. Includes Radio Haiti reporting, letter from Commissaire de Gouvernement Josué Pierre-Louis from J.J. Dominique and Michèle Montas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to violence against Radio Haiti journalists, particularly aggression against Fritzson Orius, Hughes Florvil, and Tony Vernio. Vernio was abused by justice of the peace Tulien Vincent in Port-de-Paix.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials related to the 1977-1979 lawsuit against Radio Haiti by Duvalierist attorney Constantin Mayard-Paul on behalf of the widow of Ricardo Widmaïer. Includes newspapers (Jeune Presse, Haïti-Hebdo, Le Nouveau Monde, Le Nouvelliste, Le Matin, Manchèt, Panorama, Haïti Observateur), a handwritten letter of support from "Marie Thérèse" to Jean Dominique, an open letter from "Un groupe de patriotes et de démocrates" in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One used shell casing from a bullet. Undated. Radio Haiti staff kept a jar of bullets fired at the station. This shell was found in one of the reel-to-reel boxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: By 1979, Radio Haiti had lost many of their sponsors, who were afraid of being associated with a radio station that was openly critical of the Duvalier government. In December 1979, Radio Haiti held a raffle to raise money for the station, featuring paintings by Haitian painters Valcin II, Dieudonné Cédor, Emmanuel Pierre-Charles, Casimir Joseph, G. Hector, Rose-Marie Desruisseau, Manes Descollines, Wilfrid Louis, Jocelyn Joseph, Arijac, Monfort Laguerre, and Jean Nasalio Maxi. This raffle ticket was found in the tape box for RL10059RR1538, and was apparently later used as scratch paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Full editions of the official government newspaper Le Moniteur from 1988 (presidencies of Henri Namphy, Leslie Manigat, and Prosper Avril) and 1991 (Jean-Bertrand Aristide's first presidency and the first four months of the military junta that overthrew Aristide on 30 September 1991). Folders arranged by year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Full editions of the official government newspaper Le Moniteur from 1988 (presidencies of Henri Namphy, Leslie Manigat, and Prosper Avril) and 1991 (Jean-Bertrand Aristide's first presidency and the first four months of the military junta that overthrew Aristide on 30 September 1991). Folders arranged by year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti journalist Pierre Emmanuel explains, "This was Michèle's machine. No one was allowed to touch it without special permission. It was a Marantz, but its nickname was 'Prunelle' which means "apple of my eye." She came back from exile in the United States with it [in 1986]."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This microphone first belonged to the original Radio Haiti, before Jean Dominique bought the lease in the early 1970s. It was damaged beyond repair on November 28, 1980, when Duvalier's forces destroyed the station on Rue du Quai. When Duvalier fell in 1986 and Radio Haiti returned from exile, they moved to Delmas and brought this microphone with them so they would never forget what had happened. It was crushed in the January 2010 earthquake, which damaged the Radio Haiti building so badly that it had to be torn down.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Broadcast console/mixer, made in Loveland, Colorado, featured in the opening scenes of Jonathan Demme's The Agronomist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1986 draft of the Constitution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to civil society organizations' responses to and actions around the Constitution and its implementation. Primarily the Komite Tèt Ansanm pou Onè Respè Konstitisyon-an.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials about commemorations of 29 March 1987 referendum, the 1987 Constitution and the 1801 Constitution and amendments to the Constitution. Speech by Florence Elie on the prize for the student competition on the theme of the Constitition. Text by Evens Paul of the Konvansyon Inite Demokratik (KID), "La Constitution dans l'Impasse." Also includes a Creole translation of the national anthem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the constituent assembly and creation of the 1987 Constitution. External materials include external press; open letters and petitions from grassroots groups, civil society organizations, political parties, and individuals; press releases and information from the Haitian government (mainly the Ministry of Information and Communication). Includes debates and concerns around Creole as the national language, the Conseil National de Gouvernement (CNG), and other topics relating to the creation of the Constitution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the constituent assembly and creation of the 1987 Constitution. External materials include external press; open letters and petitions from grassroots groups, civil society organizations, political parties, and individuals; press releases and information from the Haitian government (mainly the Ministry of Information and Communication), CNG decrees. Includes debates and concerns around agrarian reform, the army and police, public administration, recognition of Vodou, and other issues relating to the creation of the Constitution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the constituent assembly and creation of the 1987 Constitution. External materials include external press; open letters and petitions from grassroots groups, civil society organizations, political parties, and individuals; press releases and information from the Haitian government (mainly the Ministry of Information and Communication), CNG decrees. Includes debates and concerns around agrarian reform, the army and police, public administration, recognition of Vodou, and other issues relating to the creation of the Constitution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the creation and implementation of the 1987 Constitution, especially grassroots groups, civil society organizations and the democratic movement's perspectives on the creation of the Constitution and the immediate aftermath of the March 29 referendum. Includes the Chrétiens Sociaux Démocrates, Mouvement d'Action Démocratique (MAD), Mobilisation pour le Développement National (MDN), Lafontant Joseph, among others. Also includes anonymous ypewritten document containing suggestions on the separation of powers (executive, legislative, judiciary).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to implementation of and respect for the 1987 Constitution. Includes material from the Komite Tèt Ansanm pou Onè Respè Konstitisyon-an, Tèt Kole Ti Peyizan Ayisyen, and other grassroots and civil society groups, CATH-CLAT labor union, Parti Démocrate Chrétien Haïtien (PDCH), MDN, a text by Edouard Tardieu, text by Yves Volel of the Rassemblement des démocrates chrétiens (RDC) with one page missing, decree by Prosper Avril, among other resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the March 29, 1987 referendum on the constitution. External materials include external press; open letters and petitions from several grassroots groups, civil society organizations, political parties, and individuals; press releases and information from the Haitian government (mainly the Ministry of Information and Communication), materials from the International Center on Development Policy (US think tank), promotional material and political propaganda, CNG decrees. Also includes Radio Haiti's daily news ("interactualités") from around the country, primarily relating to the lead-up to the March 29 constitutional referendum, but occasionally including other daily miscellany. Also includes Radio Haiti materials (scripts and notes) and external materials (external press, communiqués from grassroots organizations and civil society organizations) relating to the results of the March 29, 1987 referendum on the Constitution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the March 29, 1987 referendum on the constitution. External materials include external press; open letters and petitions from several grassroots groups, civil society organizations, political parties, and individuals; press releases and information from the Haitian government (mainly the Ministry of Information and Communication), materials from the International Center on Development Policy (US think tank), promotional material and political propaganda, CNG decrees. Also includes Radio Haiti's daily news ("interactualités") from around the country, primarily relating to the lead-up to the March 29 constitutional referendum, but occasionally including other daily miscellany. Also includes Radio Haiti materials (scripts and notes) and external materials (external press, communiqués from grassroots organizations and civil society organizations) relating to the results of the March 29, 1987 referendum on the Constitution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Text of the 1987 Constitution (in several forms) including articles voted on in 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the reports and activities of the Commission Justice et Paix (Commission Episcopale Justice et Paix, Commission Episcopale Nationale Justice et Paix).

did.unittitle: Commission nationale de vérité et de justice

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Raboteau massacre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the Commission nationale de vérité et de justice (CNVJ) under Françoise Boucard, including investigation into the Raboteau massacre and other human rights violations during the coup years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the Cour de Cassation, including nominations and deaths of judges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the Cour des Comptes (Cour supérieure des comptes et du contentieux administratif, CSCCA), including Gilbert Mythil's false credentials and accusations bu Jean-Robert Sabala, the "Mains Propres" anti-corruption campaign, mismanagement of Téléco, and other topics.

did.unittitle: Fundación Arias para la Paz y el Progreso Humano

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: External materials from the 1995 Fundación Arias para la Paz y el Progreso Humano international conference in Costa Rica and Panama.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to legal matters in the late 1970s, including the Jean Dominique v. Widmaïer case (in which the latter was represented by Constantin Mayard Paul), Ernst Trouillot, and the 29 March 1979 decree.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the creation of tribunals and to judicial cases, including the trial of Luc Désir. Includes communication from Lafontant Joseph.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the creation of tribunals, judicial reform, the head of the bar association Ernst Mallebranche, and the cases of Luc Désir and Valcius Estinval, among other cases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to tribunals, court proceedings. Includes the cases of Jean Camille Musac, Jocelyn Beauchard, Paul Vericain; Eddy Moïse; assassination of Yves Volel; aftermath of the 29 November 1987 Ruelle Vaillant massacre; public prosecutor Mireille Pluviose; among other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to judicial reform, tribunals and court proceedings, including the "tribunal populaire" at Côtes-de-Fer and other grassroots justice efforts; and other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to tribunals and court proceedings, including the case of Marc Antoine Lacroix, the death of Roseline Vaval, the aftermath of the 1988 St. Jean Bosco massacre and trial of Elysée Jean François, and other cases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Provisional governments

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials related to judicial reform, tribunals and court proceedings, including the case of Marc Antoine Lacroix, Isidore Pongnon, peasant declarations against chefs de section and former macoutes, the arrest of Nicol Poitevien in connection with the 1987 Jean Rabel massacre, the arrest of Ertha Pascal Trouillot, former political prisoners' accusations against Prosper Avril, and other topics. Also includes report on arrest warrants for Williams Régala (implicated in the 1964 Jérémie Vespers massacre and the 29 November 1987 election violence), former Duvalierists, landowners implicated in the Gervais massacre, and landowners implicated in the Jean Rabel massacre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the justice system, judicial reform, court cases and tribunals in the aftermath of the coup years. Includes justice for victims of the coup d'état and FRAPH, including the aftermath of the Raboteau massacre; the Commission nationale de vérité et de justice (CNVJ); the Commission Justice et Paix; Ministry of Justice; presidential decrees (Aristide); Schiller Mathieu; the arrest of Jean Tatoune; grassroots groups including the Mouvman Peyizan Papay (MPP) and Fondation Jean-Marie Vincent; Joël Khawly; Jean Danton Léger; and other materials and topics. Also includes the second part of Radio Haiti's overview (bilan) of justice in 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the justice system, judicial reform, court cases and tribunals. Includes the Guy Malary case; charges against Claude Raymond; the aftermath of the coup years and FRAPH; the aftermath of the Raboteau massacre; Jean Danton Leger; human rights organizations; Mission Civile Internationale en Haïti (MICIVIH) and other international cooperation and efforts; the Commission Justice et Paix; the Commission nationale de vérité et de justice (CNVJ); Ministry of Justice; presidential decrees (Préval); construction of tribunals; judicial training; criminal courts; and other materials and topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the justice system, judicial reform, court cases and tribunals. Includes the Guy Malary case; charges against Claude Raymond; the aftermath of the coup years and FRAPH; the aftermath of the Raboteau massacre; Jean Danton Leger; human rights organizations; Mission Civile Internationale en Haïti (MICIVIH) and other international cooperation and efforts; the Commission Justice et Paix; the Commission nationale de vérité et de justice (CNVJ); Ministry of Justice; presidential decrees (Préval); construction of tribunals; judicial training; criminal courts; and other materials and topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Raboteau massacre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the justice system, judicial reform, court cases and tribunals. Includes criminal cases; the aftermath of the Raboteau massacre, including Castera Cenafils; ex-FADH; the Ministry of Justice, the Commission Justice et Paix; Osner Fevry; international cooperation and aid in judicial matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the justice system, judicial reform, court cases, and tribunals. Includes human rights organizations (including Fondation 30 Septembre, NCHR and POHDH), international efforts and cooperation including MICIVIH, the École de la Magistrature, criminal courts, Ministry of Justice, Luckner Pierre, police authority and police violence, ongoing justice efforts against leaders of the 1991 coup d'état, and other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the justice system, court cases, and tribunals. Includes criminal courts; MICIVIH and other forms of international cooperation; justice for victims of the coup d'état and FRAPH (including the Raboteau massacre); the Police Nationale d'Haïti (PNH) under Pierre Denizé; the assassination of ex-colonel Jean Lamy; Adolfo Pérez Esquivel; the arrest of Jean Coles Rameau; grassroots human rights organizations including Fondation 30 Septembre and POHDH; the Carrefour-Feuilles massacre; justice for the victims and commemorations of the St. Jean Bosco massacre, the Ruelle Vaillant massacre, and the Jean Rabel massacre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the justice system, court cases, and tribunals. Includes criminal courts; MICIVIH and other forms of international cooperation; justice for victims of the coup d'état and FRAPH (including the Raboteau massacre); the Police Nationale d'Haïti (PNH) under Pierre Denizé; the assassination of ex-colonel Jean Lamy; Adolfo Pérez Esquivel; the arrest of Jean Coles Rameau; grassroots human rights organizations including Fondation 30 Septembre and POHDH; the Carrefour-Feuilles massacre; justice for the victims and commemorations of the St. Jean Bosco massacre, the Ruelle Vaillant massacre, and the Jean Rabel massacre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Raboteau massacre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the justice system, court cases, and tribunals. Includes criminal courts; the Jean Dominique and Jean-Claude Louissaint assassinations; general impunity and calls for justice from international organizations, including Amnesty International and the National Coalition for Haitian Rights (NCHR); MICIVIH; justice for victims of the coup d'état, including Raboteau; open letters from Sen. Irvelt Chéry; post-election violence in Anse d'Hainault.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the justice system, tribunals and court proceedings, including the Carrefour-Feuilles massacre, the Fort Mercredi massacre, the Jean Dominique case and judge Claudy Gassant, Dongot Joseph, Gabriel Fortuné, Marjorie Rivette, Jean Sénat Fleury, Dr. Blondel Auguste, charges against former FADH, Paul Raymond and the Parti Populaire National (PPN), juvenile justice, criminal courts, investigation into the assassination of Yvon Toussaint, the PNH under Piere Denizé, among other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to the justice system, justice reform, tribunals, and court proceedings. Includes criminal courts; impunity (including the Piatre massacre and the Brignol Lindor assassination); the Jean Dominique case and judge Claudy Gassant; the Association Nationale des Magistrats Haïtiens (ANAMAH); human rights organizations including NCHR; insecurity and the PNH; the Commission Justice et Paix; Ministry of Justice; and the Forum Citoyen pour la Réforme de la Justice, among other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Undated external materials related to the justice system, including Pwogram Refòm Jidisyè pamphlet by the Ministry of Justice (likely mid-1990s), essay by Jean-André Rousseau "Pour le prestige et le renom de la justice haïtienne", POHDH statement on impunity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the Ministry of Justice under François Saint-Fleur François Latortue, Gilbert Austin, and Augustin Romain Cème, including efforts to remove and prosecute Duvalierist judges and deputies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bilan of Ministry of Justice 1996-1997. République d'Haïti Ministère de la Justice et de la Sécurité Publique: Élements d'orientation pour une réforme de la Justice en Haïti.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to the Office de la Protection du Citoyen, under Louis E. Roy and Florence Elie, including activities and human rights considerations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to security and insecurity, prison, and human rights, including MICIVIH, deportees, long-term detention of prisoners, and criminal courts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Ensekirite; Police; Human Rights

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about arrests, including arrests of "zenglendo" and gang leaders and arrests of dissidents and activists. Also includes Grégory Brandt's arrest by US authorities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials related to ensekirite, violence, gang activity, and police interventions in Cité Soleil.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to disarmament, primarily disarmament of former army and FRAPH in the mid-late 1990s, and disarmament of gangs in Cité Soleil in 2002. Includes efforts by the PNH, MINUHA, Viva Rio, and other actors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to "ensekirite" (lawlessness and violence) in 1986-1987. Includes surveillance by local vigilance brigades and comités de quartier, arson, shootings, murders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Army; St. Jean Bosco massacre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to "ensekirite" (lawlessness and violence) in 1988. Includes aggression against Radio Soleil, surveillance by vigilance brigades, attacks by attachés and Macoutes, shootings, and other subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to "ensekirite" (lawlessness and violence) in 1989. Includes surveillance by brigades de vigilance, shootings and murders, including the assassination of Grégory Delpé. ANADIPP closes gas stations at night to prevent attacks, which affects transport schedules.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to "ensekirite" (lawlessness and violence) in 1990. Includes surveillance by brigades de vigilance, murders, shootings, robberies, information relating to the attack on pro-Aristide demonstrators on December 5; also dechoukaj of supporters of the Lafontant coup. Reactions from political parties, army, civil society organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials (external press, press releases) relating to "ensekirite" (lawlessness and violence) in early 1991 just before and just after Aristide comes into power. Includes the February arson fire at Aristide's Lafanmi Selavi orphanage; the violent criminals known as "zenglendo"; several murders including that of blind musician Ulrick Pierre (Ti Pierre), Canadian priest Alain Pagé, and others; "dechoukaj" (the violent removal of Macoutes and Duvalierists) and "Pè Lebrun" ("necklacing," the lynching of people by forcing a rubber tire around their necks and setting it on fire); the 27 January 1991 violence in Carrefour in which eleven people were killed by the military; and other incidents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about ensekirite (lawlessness and violence) throughout Haiti in 1995. Includes shootings, murders, attacks by zenglendo and gangs, police activity, electoral violence, violent demonstrations, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about ensekirite (lawlessness and violence) throughout Haiti in 1996. Includes shootings, murders, attacks by zenglendo and gangs, drug trade, police activity, violent demonstrations, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials relating to "ensekirite" (lawlessness and violence) throughout Haiti in 1997. Includes gang violence and antigang measures, "zenglendo", PNH, Sécretaire d'Etat à la Sécurité Publique Robert Manuel, firearms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about crime, lawlessness, murders, shootings, police activity, and violence throughout Haiti. Includes in particular events in Milot, Mirebalais, and Habitation Leclerc in Port-au-Prince.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about crime, lawlessness, murders, shootings, police activity, and violence throughout Haiti. Includes reactions by organisations populaires and civil society organizations. Also includes small amounts of material about violence abroad (USA, Jamaica.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about crime, lawlessness, murders, shootings, police activity, and violence throughout Haiti. Includes reactions by organisations populaires and civil society organizations. Also includes small amounts of material about violence abroad (USA, Jamaica.)

Includes the disappearance of Félix Bien-Aimé, former director of the National Cemetery and Aristide partisan, and violence in Martissant after Bien-Aimé's disappearance. Also includes kidnappings, gang violence.

Folders are arranged by year.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Duvalierism and Macoutism

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about prisons and political prisoners during the presidency of Jean-Claude Duvalier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about prisons (particularly the Pénitencier National) and prison conditions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about prisons and prison conditions during the presidencies of Jean-Bertrand Aristide and René Préval. Includes the Administration Pénitentiaire Nationale (APENA) and the UN mission MICIVIH.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about prisons and prison conditions. Includes APENA, NCHR claims about prisoners' rights and other subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: See also: Jean Dominique assassination; Fanmi Lavalas; Organisations populaires

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio Haiti materials and external materials about Ronald "Cadavre" Camille.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One photocopy of a black-and-white photo of a man looking at a poster for "Mais, je suis belle," the documentary about Black beauty contests that Jean Dominique produced along with Édouard Guilbaud and Emmanuel Lafond. June 1962.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photos of Radio Haiti in the late 1960s and early 1970s. Includes a photograph of Jean Dominique's 38th birthday (31 July 1968) at Radio Haiti's station on the Grand-Rue in Port-au-Prince, with sound technician Ramil, Jean-Claude Charles, Jocelyne Dominique, Marcus Garcia, Bob Lemoine Joe Thony (Ti Tonton), and Jean-Marie Pétion. Thirteen photos of the interior of Radio Haiti's Grand-Rue station from around 1970. One photo in the studio of Radio Haiti's Rue-du-Quai station from around 1971, with Mona Chéry, singer Yole (Ledan) Derose, actress Jessie Alphonse, Jacques Jean-Baptiste, Harold Isaac, and possibly Jessie Alphonse's sister, Jocelyne Alphonse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photos of Richard Brisson, poet, actor, and Radio Haiti's station manager, who was executed by the Duvalier regime in January 1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Large black-and-white photograph of Jean Dominique with CATH labor union members Cangé Abel, Kedner Astier, and Georges Etienne after leaving the Venezuelan embassy in Port-au-Prince and on their way to Caracas. They had sought refuge in the embassy following the violent events of 28 November 1980.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nine color photographs of Jean Dominique and Konpè Filo (Anthony Pascal) in the studios of WNYE in New York, where they hosted a Creole-language radio program, "Radyo Ayiti nan Nouyòk."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twenty-nine black-and-white photographs of the damage inflicted on the Radio Haiti station on Rue-du-Quai by Duvalier's forces on 28 November 1980. Includes photos of the studio, newsroom, Jean Dominique's office and other rooms. These photos were taken in February 1986, after the fall of Duvalier. Also includes an inventory of the damage, compiled by Jan J. Dominique from 13 to 22 February 1986 and submitted to a justice of the peace.

did.unittitle: Return of Jean Dominique and Michèle Montas

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twenty color photos and two black-and-white photographs of Jean Dominique's and Michèle Montas's return to Haiti in March 1986, after the fall of Duvalier. Includes photos from the airport runway, the area around the airport, and Rue-du-Quai. Features Dominique, Montas, Jan J. Dominique, Frankétienne, and other family and supporters. Includes several photos of crowds of supporters carrying signs, posters, and banners, as well as Dominique lifted up by the crowd. Syto Cavé appears in one photo, in the crowd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six black-and-white photos of the return of Konpè Filo in 1986 after the fall of Duvalier.

did.unittitle: Solidarity campaign to rebuild Radio Haiti

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three color photographs of the solidarity campaign to rebuild Radio Haiti in 1986. Include Jean Dominique, Jan J. Dominique, Konpè Filo, Marvel Dandin, and others (including some children).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three photos of Jean Dominique supervising the rebuilding of Radio Haiti in 1994, after the end of the coup years. Includes a cameraman, likely from The Agronomist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seven color photographs of Radio Haiti's 60th anniversary celebration, on 17 September 1995. Includes Michèle Montas, Jan J. (J.J.) Dominique, Nadine Dominique, Sony Estéus, Jean Claude (Fanfan) Mathieu; Guerlande Éloi, Jean Roland Chery, Maggy Dazema, Pierre Emmanuel (Manno), Wilfrid Lavaud (Ti Do), Paul (Paulo) Dubois, Fritson Orius, Georges Muller Polistin, Septimus André, Edouarzin Dionisse, Godefroy Boursiquot, musician Beethova Obas, and Prime Minister Smarck Michel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six color photos of President René Préval's visit to the Artibonite with ODVA members to observe agrarian reform. Jean Dominique accompanied. Includes Préval, Dominique, Michèle Montas, Minister of Agriculture François Séverin, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various photos. Includes a photo of the exterior of the Radio Haiti station on Rue du Quai, taken by Michael Hooper (1981); a photo of Jean Dominique during the solidarity campaign to reopen Radio Haiti (1986); a photograph of Jean Dominique and Jean-Bertrand Aristide in the studio; a photo of Jean Dominique, Aristide, and Aristide's wife Mildred (circa 1991). Also includes a photograph of Jean Dominique at a press conference, labeled "Minis. Information Jacques Lorthé, télévision. Of Lorthé, it was said that Dominique "cut him down with a strike of his microphone" ("li desann misye avèk yon kout mikwo"). Includes a photo from the 14 August 1999 symbolic "funeral" for imported ethanol, held by sugar planters in Léogâne and featuring René Préval, among others. Also includes a photograph of Michèle Montas working at her desk at Radio Haiti, circa 1990s.

did.unittitle: Jean Dominique and Jean-Claude Louissaint funeral, peasant wake, Passe Canot

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two photographs of Sony Estéus speaking at the funeral for Jean Dominique and Jean-Claude Louissaint at Stade Sylvio Cator on 8 April 2000. Four photos of the wake organized by peasant farmers in Pont-Sondé on 15 April 2000, with Michèle Montas and Grégory Casimir. Eleven photographs of the ceremony to spread Dominique's ashes in the Artibonite River at Passe Canot on 16 April 2000. Features Michèle Montas, J.J. Dominique, Charles Suffrard, René Préval, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thirteen color photographs from the inauguration of the Centre de Production Agricole Jean Dominique in Marmelade/Beauché, Artibonite, on 29 July 2000. With Michèle Montas, J.J. Dominique, René Préval, Nadine Dominique, François Séverin, and others. Fifteen color photographs of the commemoration of Jean Dominique's 70th birthday in l'Estère, Artibonite, on 31 July 2000. With Michèle Montas, Charles Suffrard, René Préval, and many others, including children. Also includes two color photos from a related nighttime event, with Syto Cavé and Monique Lafontant, among others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photos from 10 December 2000, when Michèle Montas received the first Michael S. Hooper Award from the National Coalition for Haitian Rights for her and Jean Dominique's work. Includes Montas, Jocelyn McCalla, Edwidge Danticat, Jonathan Demme, Danny Glover, and Max Dougé.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nine photos from a screening of Jonathan Demme's "The Agronomist" in Montreal, circa 2004. With Michèle Montas, J.J. Dominique, Nadine Dominique, Michaëlle Jean, Kym Dominique-Ferguson, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eight black-and-white of Jean Dominique working with peasant farmers in Bayeux (northern Haiti) on sisal production.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eighteen photos of Jean Dominique and his family, including his parents Léopold Dominique and Marcelle Pereira, sister Madeleine Paillère and brother Philippe Dominique, and other siblings. Includes childhood photos of Dominique as a Boy Scout, in a clown costume, and dressed for his first communion, among other childhood photos. Also includes photos of Dominique as a young man with his sister Micheline. Also includes two photos of the family house on Avenue Magny in Port-au-Prince, presumably taken in the 1990s or 2000.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four photos taken during the return of Jean Dominique and Michèle Montas to Haiti in March 1986, after the fall of Jean-Claude Duvalier. Includes two black-and-white photos of Dominique on the runway, one color photo of Dominique, and a group in front of the old Radio Haiti station on Rue du Quai with a banner: "Kafou ak Matisan vle Radio Haïti-Inter."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two portraits of Jean Dominique and Michèle Montas on their wedding day, 28 July 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five photographs of Jean Dominique and CATH members during their exile from Haiti to Venezuela in December 1980. Includes passport photos of Dominique and CATH members Cangé Abel, Kedner Astier, and Georges Etienne, and photos with Arnold Antonin, presumably in Caracas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twenty-seven photos of Jean Dominique and Michèle Montas, primarily in the United States and France and primarily with family. Includes several photos taken during travels in France with Dominique's younger sister Micheline. Also includes a photo with Dominique's brother Gérard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nineteen photos of Jean Dominique in various settings. Includes portraits; photos with Michèle Montas and J.J. Dominique; two photos with Jean-Bertrand Aristide, one of which includes his wife Mildred (likely 1991); and photos with peasant farmers (circa 1996-1999).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two photographs of Jean Dominique with his older sister, Madeleine Paillère, upon the publication of her novel INSELBADJO in 1978.

did.unittitle: Mais, je suis belle and Ciné Club
did.container: Mais, je suis belle and Ciné Club

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three photographs. One black-and-white photo of a man looking at a poster for "Mais, je suis belle," the documentary about Black beauty contests that Jean Dominique produced along with Édouard Guilbaud and Emmanuel Lafond. June 1962. One photograph of the "Mais, je suis belle" production, with Dominique in the foreground. One photo of Ciné Club members on a bus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twelve color photographs. In 1986, sound engineers Miles Smith and Jane Pipik traveled to Haiti to help Radio Haiti open its station on Route de Delmas after the fall of Duvalier. These photos show construction, sound insulation with burlap, and studio equipment. Features Jean Dominique, his sister Micheline Billot-Dominique and her husband Jean Billot, daughter Dolores Neptune, and Miles Smith. Also includes a photo of a painting of Radio Haiti tied to a cross. The painting is from 1980, and the inscription reads (in translation): "The proverb goes: each firefly lights the way for itself [every man for himself]. We say: unity makes strength. Let's help Radio Haiti-Inter lay its cross down so that it is not crucified."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twelve photos featuring the life of the Radio Haiti station. One photo from the late 1970s of Marvel Dandin, Liliane Pierre-Paul, Jacques Jean-Baptiste, and Sonny Bastien at the microphone. Two photos of Radio Haiti's solidarity campaign to reopen the station in 1986, with Jean Dominique and Frankétienne. Several photos of Jean Dominique in his office. One photo of Madeleine Paillère, Michèle Montas, and J.J. Dominique. Seven color photographs of Radio Haiti's 60th anniversary celebration, on 17 September 1995. Includes Michèle Montas, Jan J. (J.J.) Dominique, Nadine Dominique, Sony Estéus, Jean Claude (Fanfan) Mathieu; Guerlande Éloi, Jean Roland Chery, Maggy Dazema, Pierre Emmanuel (Manno), Wilfrid Lavaud (Ti Do), Paul (Paulo) Dubois, Fritson Orius, Georges Muller Polistin, musician Beethova Obas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three photographs of Jean Dominique as a young man, studying in France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six PCT files that could not be converted to TIF. Contents unknown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Posters and maps collected by Radio Haiti. Includes one poster by the Ligue des Anciens Prisonniers Politiques (L.A.P.P.H.) featuring photos of victims of Duvalierist violence arranged into the shape of the Fort-Dimanche prison (26 April 1987); a map of urban traffic in Port-au-Prince (14 February 1978); two topographical maps of the Citadelle, Sans-Souci palace and Ramiers (March 1978); a poster-sized political cartoon by Philippe Dodard from Le Nouvelliste, addressing the "boat people" crisis, the energy crisis, and other issues during the Jean-Claude Duvalier years (December 1981); two posters from the UNESCO-sponsored "Prix Jean Dominique pour la Liberté de la Presse" (3 May 2002); "Jounal Jenn Yo" cartoon on AIDS stigma by PSI Haiti (December 1997); poster by S.O.F.A. (Solidarite Fanm Ayisyèn) for 25 November (International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women) featuring a painting by Valcin II (undated, likely 1980s); UDEP poster on the democratization of government-owned enterprises (c. 1995); two Reporters Sans Frontières posters naming many members of Jean-Bertrand Aristide's government as responsible for the deaths of Jean Dominique and Brignol Lindor, including graphic images of Dominique's and Lindor's bodies (February 2002); one Reporters Sans Frontières poster "En Haïti, les assassins font-ils la loi?" calling for justice for Jean Dominique (April 2003).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Issue of "Haiti: Démocratie Nouvelle" newspaper, published on Brooklyn, N.Y., with cover story on the arrival of Jean Dominique and CATH members Cangé Abel, Kedner Astier, and Georges Etienne in Caracas following the violence events of 28 November 1980. Also includes an editorial on the Fondation Michèle B. Duvalier, the tribulations of K-Plim, and other stories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous audio materials from Radio Haiti that were not digitized. Includes nine cassette copies of previously-digitized Radio Haiti programs, and one "JLD interview avec journal Taptap" from 1989-09-18 that was not digitized. Also includes four CDs, which include songs and poems in tribute to Jean Dominique (including a poem by Clotaire Saint-Natus), and a Creole-language Voice of America report on justice for Jean Dominique from 2001.

did.unittitle: Charlie Rose: Should We Invade Haiti?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jean Dominique, Rev. Jesse Jackson, Les Gelb of the Council on Foreign Relations, and Republican Senator Judd Gregg react to Bill Clinton's speech promoting an invasion of Haiti to overthrow the military junta of Raoul Cédras and reinstate Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Journalist Andrew Neil discusses the possibility of a US invasion of Haiti and other subjects.

did.unittitle: "This Week in South Florida" with Jean Dominique and Ian Martin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Michael Putney of This Week In South Florida interviews Jean Dominique and British human rights advocate Ian Martin of MICIVIH about whether economic sanctions will be enough to force the military regime from power or whether military intervention will be necessary. Dominique says that the phone call option is always there  the US government could simply phone General Cédras and tell him to leave. Martin describes the Haitian army as a force of internal repression that was created by the United States. They discuss the Governors Island accord and the US governments decision to withdraw the USS Harlan County from Haitian waters after armed thugs affiliated with the military regime demonstrated at the docks.

did.unittitle: KRS-One on H.E.A.L. (Human Education Against Lies)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Various clips of hip-hop artist KRS-One, released by the organization he co-founded, H.E.A.L. (Human Education Against Lies). He discusses the importance of intellect over memory, colonial exploitation of Africa, the "Stop the Violence" movement, and the song "Self Destruction." Undated, early 1990s.

did.unittitle: Jonathan Demme on Jean Dominique's assassination, Charlie Rose

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four days after Jean Dominique's assassination, Jonathan Demme speaks to Charlie Rose about Dominique's life and death. Demme declares that it is not known who killed Dominique, but the United States is partly responsible for his death due to their repeated efforts to undermine democracy in Haiti. Includes a clip of Dominique on Charlie Rose's show in 1994.

did.unittitle: Vodou: Haiti's Eternal Promise (demo tape), Kartemquin Films

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Demo tape for a film called "Vodou: Haiti's Eternal Promise." Narrated by scholar William Balan-Gaubert, who discusses Lakou Souvenance, death rituals and the "peyi san chapo," among other topics. The full film will explore the lives of Esther, an eleven-year-old girl who grew up in Lakou Souvenance and who is a Vodou drummer, and the Haitian singer Marjorie Beaubrun, who grew up Protestant and became a Vodou adherent later in life.

did.unittitle: CBS news report on Yves Volel's assassination

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Victoria Corderi reports from Port-au-Prince on the assassination of presidential candidate Yves Volel. Jean Dominique describes violence by Macoutes that seek to intimidate people so they do not vote in the 29 November 1987 elections.

did.unittitle: NBC news report on democratization of Haiti and the return of Jean Dominique

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Hart reports from Haiti on the return of Jean Dominique in March 1986. Includes footage of Dominique arriving at the airport in Port-au-Prince. Dominique describes how broadcasting in Haitian Creole, with its "mmhmmms" and other nonverbal utterances, allowed people to express their beliefs without stating them: in one mmmhmm, "there is three Macoutes involved." Dominique explains the exploitation of the Haitian poor by the Macoutes and the chefs de section, and how the dechoukaj of Macoute elements from the government must not also destroy the good parts of the government. Also includes a report from Parisse, in the Nord-Est, where people describe their poverty and their hopes for democracy. (Tape also includes a brief report on Radio Martí, which broadcasts news from the US to Cuba; President Ronald Reagan declares, "Cuba sí, Castro no." Also includes what appears to be raw footage of the aftermath of a collision between a bus and a car on I-95 in Miami.)
